Penn's first colonial Quaker ventures were the Jersey Provinces (Jersey loves it when you display you're envy of the place) - East & West from which he learned from his mistakes. Am researching Penn's colony for a book at the moment and it turns out that the place wasn't quite the beacon of virtuosity that many think - most noteworthy being their participation in the slave trade. Serious attempts to curb the slave trade only started 50 years after the colony was founded and a successful attempt to curb it was 20 years behind that. Too many rich Quakers were making too much money off the trade and William Penn himself stated he'd much prefer to own a slave that he would have forever than an indentured servant who would leave in 7 years. Being drunk in public was against the law, not drinking - the first place built and opened in Philadelphia was a pub, the Blue Anchor and the first brewery opened within a year of the first arrivals. They had an exorbitant number of establishments serving alcohol - close to 150 licensed ones on 2nd Avenue in 1730.

NY Stock exchange on Wall Street is a Dutch import as well, modeled on the 'Beurs van Berlage' in Amsterdam. Virtually all of the laws in the US that guarantee civil rights came from the Dutch legal system because, as a condition of surrender, the English had to guarantee the continuation of all rights afforded under Dutch law. These then became the basis for other jurisdictions - not Plymouth, Virginia, or Massachusetts colony. The Dutch also effected a change in English law when the Anglo-Dutch Wars were brought to a close with the House of Orange taking the throne in 1688. Of course, the Spanish had been in the future US for over 40 years before the pilgrims landed at Plymouth Rock but their impact on the laws of the nation was minimal.

Interesting fact. When the Dutch controlled Manhattan they also controlled 9 of the 10 islands (all in the pacific) where nutmeg could be grown. England controlled the other one. Wanting a monopoly on nutmeg (incredibly rare at the time and so a great commodity) the Dutch invaded the final Island and forced the English people out. The dutch comprehensively beat the English in a small battle (can't remember the details) as the islands were far away from Europe and the British were vastly outnumbered (by roughly 9 to 1). To prevent war the Dutch offered England compensation in the way of a much less valuable (at the time) island: Manhattan.

That's really all I'm trying to say. It seemed people got on John for calling German-speakers who came from the geographical region known as Germany... Well, German. For the sake of the discussion of history, there is nothing wrong with calling German-speaking immigrants that came to America from Germany German. They were more than likely called such by the Brits, French, and just about everyone else there.

But what would a German immigrant be called by everyone else in America?

Not "That German-speaker". I doubt they'd be called an "Oldenburger" or something of that nature either. They'd more than likely just be called "German" because they come from the geographical and cultural region known as "Germany." While nationalism wasn't much of a thing prior to the 19th century, there was still very obviously a German nation beforehand.

I understand you'r argument. But keep in mind that in the 17th century germans didn't have a state, not even a nationality in the strict sense. We called them germans now, but in 17th century a german would never define himself as a german. Ideas such as nationality and ethnicity only were adopted in the later half of the 19th century. Before that people only defined themselves by the village or community they were part of.

The British crown was united by James the 1st or 6th, depending on your perspective, at his coronation in July of 1603.  The Scots agreed to form greater economic bonds with England as well as surrender all legislative control not previously reserved for the King to form Great Britain in 1707 after a failed attempt to colonize Panama which successfully lost Scotland a full 1/6th of it's wealth.  But the union of 1707 probably won't have happened at all if the monarchy hadn't united first.

Germany as we know it did not exist until 1871, when the Germanic states were officially unified. Before that date, what we know as Germany was a collection of independent states, the most powerful and influential of which was Prussia. It was they who spearheaded the effort to bring the Germanic states under a common flag.

Nationalism is retrogressive and is responsible  for perpetuating divisions between people. It's really puerile when you get to thinking about it.
